questions.text: The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) uses both cellular and paracellular transport mechanisms. The apical membrane has an expanded surface area available for reabsorption and tight junctions enabling high-capacity fluid reabsorption. Which of the following is true regarding the function and transporters of the PCT?

choices.text: Parathyroid hormone stimulates Ca2+/Na exchange within the PCT
65-80% of sodium is reabsorbed in PCT
Sodium hydrogen exchange is regulated by aldosterone
Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of PCT

questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) uses both cellular and paracellular transport mechanisms. Its apical membrane has an expanded surface area available for reabsorption created by brush borders and tight junctions enabling high-capacity fluid reabsorption.  The PCT reabsorbs all glucose and amino acids and most bicarbonate, sodium, chloride, phosphate, potassium, water, and uric acid. Around 67% of the sodium that gets filtered into  tubular fluid is reabsorbed in the PCT. The PCT also generates and secretes ammonium into the tubular fluid while bicarbonate is reabsorbed back into the blood. Lastly, parathyroid hormone, when released, inhibits Na+/PO43 cotransport in the PCT, thereby increasing phosphate excretion.

The transporters in the PCT and their functions are as follows:

  • Na+-glucose cotransporter: moves Na+ in the direction of its concentration gradient, and uses that energy to move glucose into the cell.  
  • Na+/K+ ATPase: pumps Na+ out through the basolateral side into the interstitium, requires ATP.  
  • Na-H+ exchanger: one sodium ion into the cell in exchange for one hydrogen ion out of the cell with associated bicarbonate (HCO3-) reabsorption. Angiotensin II stimulates this transporter permitting contraction alkalosis in case of hypotension/renal hypoperfusion. 
  • A sodium bicarbonate cotransporter on the basolateral surface transports bicarbonate and sodium into the bloodstream. 

Option Analysis

❌ It is impermeable to water:
Incorrect: The PCT reabsorbs all glucose and amino acids and most HCO3–, Na+, Cl–, PO43–, K+, H2O, and uric acid. The thick ascending loop of Henle and early distal convoluted tubule are impermeable to water.  
❌ Parathyroid hormone stimulates Ca2+/Na exchange within the PCT:
Incorrect: Parathyroid hormone stimulates the Ca2+/Na exchange in the early distal convoluted tubule. In the PCT, parathyroid hormone inhibits Na+/PO43– cotransport, thereby increasing phosphate excretion.  
✅ 65-80% of sodium is reabsorbed in PCT:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sodium hydrogen exchange is regulated by aldosterone:
Incorrect: Sodium is reabsorbed in exchange for hydrogen and potassium ions excretion in the collecting duct and is regulated by aldosterone. In the PCT, angiotensin II stimulates Na+/H+ exchange, thereby increasing sodium, water, and bicarbonate reabsorption (permitting contraction alkalosis).  
❌ Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of PCT:
Incorrect: The Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of the thick ascending loop of Henle.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying differences between nephrons of the kangaroo rat and humans. They find that the kangaroo rat has a relatively long loop of Henle, allowing the osmolarity at the bend to reach over 3000 mOsm/L. They discover a process of using energy to generate an osmotic gradient that enables both rats and humans to reabsorb water from tubular fluid and produce concentrated urine. Which of the following terms best describes the process described in the stem above?
questions.solution:
The stem above describes the phenomenon known as kidney countercurrent multiplication, a key physiologic mechanism to conserve body water. During this process, electrolytes are actively moved from the urine to the interstitium in the ascending limb (e.g. through the Na+/K+/Cl- pump), so urine becomes more dilute. Next, water is passively driven into the interstitium via the descending limb, due to this concentration gradient, thus concentrating urine. Mammals like the kangaroo rat have exceptionally long loops of Henle to further increase this gradient, allowing for increased passive reabsorption of water given the dry desert climate in which they reside.

Patients with intrinsic acute kidney injury lose this ability to further concentrate urine, resulting in urine osmolalities of 300 to 350 mOsm/kg, a value that is similar to plasma osmolality. In contrast, pre-renal injury often results in higher urine osmolalities due to the kidney’s ability to continue to concentrate urine (500 mOsm/kg).

Option Analysis

✅ Kidney countercurrent multiplication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Effective renal plasma flow:
Incorrect: Effective renal plasma flow is a measure used in renal physiology to calculate renal plasma flow (RPF) and estimate renal function. Para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) is often used as a surrogate marker.  
❌ Renal tubular acidosis:
Incorrect: Renal tubular acidosis refers to a disorder of the renal tubules that causes normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Filtration fraction:
Incorrect: Filtration fraction is defined as the ratio of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) over the renal plasma flow. The filtration fraction represents the proportion of fluid reaching the kidneys that pass into the renal tubules.  
❌ Solvent drag:
Incorrect: Solvent drag refers to solutes in ultrafiltrate that are transported back from the renal tubule by the flow of water rather than specifically by ion pumps or other membrane transport proteins.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man who previously lived at sea level moves to a new city in the mountains. Which of the following changes are expected to be seen after 6 months of living at a higher elevation?
questions.solution:
Erythropoietin (EPO) is a glycoprotein that stimulates red blood cell synthesis in the bone marrow. It is mainly produced in the peritubular cells of the renal cortex, although a tiny fraction is produced by other organs (mainly the liver).

EPO synthesis and release are directly controlled by tissue hypoxia. Under normal conditions, a small amount is produced to maintain normal red blood cell (RBC) production. However, when PaO2 drops, the synthesis of EPO increases significantly to stimulate additional RBC production.

When the kidney tubular cells receive normal amounts of oxygen, oxygen hydroxylates the alpha-portion of a factor called hypoxia-induced factor (HIF). This change tags the HIF for ubiquitination and destruction. However, when oxygen supply decreases, the alpha segment of HIF is not hydroxylated or destroyed. Therefore, HIF remains in the cell and diffuses to the nucleus, increasing the synthesis of EPO mRNA and eventually leading to increased EPO production.

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Hypoxia (e.g. living in high altitudes) causes increased erythropoietin production and increased red blood cell (RBC) synthesis. However, the RBC lifespan does not change.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Increased red blood cell count in patients exposed to hypoxic conditions for prolonged periods is secondary to increased erythropoietin production.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These changes may be present in the setting of a primary bone marrow malignancy (e.g. polycythemia vera), resulting in increased red blood cell (RBC) synthesis independent of erythropoietin levels. However, this patient recently moved to a city located at high elevation and is expected to have increased erythropoietin levels and increased RBC count.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Reduced oxygen content at high altitudes leads to increased erythropoietin and red blood cell count.

questions.text: A study is performed to understand the fluid compartments of the body. Researchers divide body fluid compartments into two main categories: intracellular and extracellular. Extracellular gets further subdivided into interstitial fluid and plasma. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Potassium ion concentration is higher in extracellular fluid than in intracellular fluid
Sodium ion concentration is higher in the intracellular compartment than in the extracellular compartment
The highest amount of water in all compartments is found in the intestinal compartment
The highest amount of water in all compartments is found in the plasma compartment
The interstitial fluid has a slightly higher concentration of chloride ions than plasma

questions.solution:
The human body primarily comprises water, accounting for approximately 60% of total body weight. Body fluid compartments are divided into both intracellular and extracellular compartments, with the extracellular compartment further subdivided into the interstitium and the plasma.   

The majority of total body water is found in the intracellular compartment, accounting for approximately ⅔ of the total body water (or 40% of the total body weight). In comparison, the extracellular compartment accounts for ⅓ of the total body water (or 20% of the total body weight). Of the fluid in the extracellular compartment, 75% is found in the interstitial fluid, and the remaining 25% is found in plasma.  

In addition, ion concentration differs between the extracellular and intracellular compartments and the plasma and interstitium. Higher concentrations of potassium and magnesium ions are found in the intracellular compartment, while the concentrations of sodium and chloride ions are higher in the extracellular compartment. In the interstitium, a higher concentration of small anions (e.g. Chloride) occurs, while in plasma, there is a slightly higher concentration of cations (e.g. Sodium). This difference exists due to negatively charged proteins, which cannot leave the plasma.  

Option Analysis

❌ Potassium ion concentration is higher in extracellular fluid than in intracellular fluid  :
Incorrect: Potassium ions concentration is higher in the intracellular compartments than in the extracellular compartments.  
❌ Sodium ion concentration is higher in the intracellular compartment than in the extracellular compartment:
Incorrect: Sodium ion concentration in the extracellular compartment is higher than the intracellular concentration.
❌ The highest amount of water in all compartments is found in the intestinal compartment  :
Incorrect: The highest amount of water is found in the intracellular compartment, accounting for two-thirds of total body water.
❌ The highest amount of water in all compartments is found in the plasma compartment  :
Incorrect: The highest amount of water is found in the intracellular compartment, accounting for two-thirds of total body water.  
✅ The interstitial fluid has a slightly higher concentration of chloride ions than plasma  :
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate his altered mental status after being found down while working outdoors on a hot sunny day. He had two episodes of non-bloody, nonbilious emesis before arrival. His temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg. Mucous membranes are dry. Which of the following changes will likely be observed in the glomerular function of this patient?
questions.solution:
During states of severe dehydration, a significant drop in blood pressure reduces renal plasma flow (RPF) and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) despite renal autoregulatory mechanisms (these mechanisms begin failing with sustained systolic blood pressures below 80 mmHg).

In response, renin is released from granular cells and causes a cascade of reactions that result in the production of angiotensin II and subsequent vasoconstriction of the efferent arteriole. This effect increases glomerular hydrostatic pressure and slightly improves GFR, but not to normal levels. In addition, vasoconstriction of the efferent arteriole reduces the RPF even further. The overall effect is an increase in filtration fraction (FF), which is the ratio of GFR/RPF.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Constriction of the ureter can decrease GFR without affecting the RPF, resulting in decreased FF.   
❌ :
Incorrect: In the absence of prostaglandin, unopposed vasoconstriction of the afferent arterioles occurs, leading to a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal plasma flow (RPF). This change does not affect the filtration fraction, which is defined as the ratio of GFR/RPF.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Angiotensin II evokes vasoconstriction of the efferent arteriole, resulting in an elevated glomerular filtration rate (GFR), reduced renal plasma flow (RPF), and an increase in filtration fraction (FF).   
❌ :
Incorrect: A decrease in serum plasma protein decreases oncotic pressure and results in more fluid being filtered via the kidney, thus increasing the GFR and thereby FF.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation
